section.heading: Office of Multimodal Freight Infrastructure and Policy

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: Department.—
paragraph.content: The term “Department” means the Department of Transportation.

paragraph.heading: Freight office.—
paragraph.content: The term “Freight Office” means the Office of Multimodal Freight Infrastructure and Policy established under subsection (b).

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Transportation.

subsection.heading: Establishment.—
subsection.content: The Secretary shall establish within the Department an Office of Multimodal Freight Infrastructure and Policy.

subsection.heading: Purposes.—
subsection.chapeau: The purposes of the Freight Office shall be—

paragraph.content: to carry out the national multimodal freight policy described in section 70101;
to administer and oversee certain multimodal freight grant programs within the Department in accordance with subsection (d);
to promote and facilitate the sharing of information between the private and public sectors with respect to freight issues;
to conduct research on improving multimodal freight mobility, and to oversee the freight research activities of the various agencies within the Department;
to assist cities and States in developing freight mobility and supply chain expertise;
to liaise and coordinate with other Federal departments and agencies; and
to carry out other duties, as prescribed by the Secretary.

subsection.heading: Administration of Policies and Programs.—
subsection.chapeau: The Freight Office shall—

paragraph.chapeau: develop and manage—

subparagraph.content: the national freight strategic plan described in section 70102; and
the National Multimodal Freight Network established under section 70103;
oversee the development and updating of the State freight plans described in section 70202; and
provide guidance or best practices relating to the development and updating of State freight plans under that section;
administer multimodal freight grant programs, including multimodal freight grants established under section 117 of title 23; and
establish procedures for analyzing and evaluating applications for grants under those programs;

paragraph.chapeau: assist States in the establishment of—

subparagraph.content: State freight advisory committees under section 70201; and
multi-State freight mobility compacts under section 70204; and

paragraph.content: provide to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics input regarding freight data and planning tools.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Freight Office shall be headed by an Assistant Secretary for Multimodal Freight, who shall—

subparagraph.content: be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
have professional standing and demonstrated knowledge in the field of freight transportation.

paragraph.heading: Duties.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Assistant Secretary shall—

subparagraph.content: report to the Under Secretary of Transportation for Policy;
be responsible for the management and oversight of the activities, decisions, operations, and personnel of the Freight Office;
work with the modal administrations of the Department to encourage multimodal collaboration; and
carry out such additional duties as the Secretary may prescribe.

heading.inline: Consolidation and Elimination of Duplicative Offices.—

paragraph.heading: Consolidation of offices and office functions.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may consolidate into the Freight Office any office or office function within the Department that the Secretary determines has duties, responsibilities, resources, or expertise that support the purposes of the Freight Office.

paragraph.heading: Elimination of offices.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary may eliminate any office within the Department if the Secretary determines that—

subparagraph.content: the purposes of the office are duplicative of the purposes of the Freight Office;
the office or the functions of the office have been substantially consolidated with the Freight Office pursuant to paragraph (1);
the elimination of the office will not adversely affect the requirements of the Secretary under any Federal law; and
the elimination of the office will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the programs and functions conducted by the office.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary shall ensure that the Freight Office is adequately staffed and funded.

subparagraph.heading: Transfer of positions to freight office.—
subparagraph.content: Subject to subparagraph (B), the Secretary may transfer to the Freight Office any position within any other office of the Department if the Secretary determines that the position is necessary to carry out the purposes of the Freight Office.

subparagraph.heading: Requirement.—
subparagraph.content: If the Secretary transfers a position to the Freight Office pursuant to subparagraph (A), the Secretary, in coordination with the appropriate modal administration of the Department, shall ensure that the transfer of the position does not adversely affect the requirements of the modal administration under any Federal law.

heading.inline: Transfer of funds from consolidated or eliminated offices.—

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.content: To carry out the purposes of the Freight Office, the Secretary may transfer to the Freight Office from any office or office function that is consolidated or eliminated under subsection (f) any funds allocated for the consolidated or eliminated office or office function.

clause.heading: Retransfer.—
clause.content: Any portion of any funds or limitations of obligations transferred to the Freight Office pursuant to clause (i) may be transferred back to, and merged with, the original account.

heading.inline: Transfer of funds allocated for administrative costs.—

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.content: The Secretary may transfer to the Freight Office any funds allocated for the administrative costs of the programs referred to in subsection (d)(3).

clause.heading: Retransfer.—
clause.content: Any portion of any funds or limitations of obligations transferred to the Freight Office pursuant to clause (i) may be transferred back to, and merged with, the original account.

paragraph.heading: Description of freight office.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Secretary shall make publicly available on the website of the Department a description of the Freight Office, including a description of—

subparagraph.content: the programs managed or made available by the Freight Office; and
the eligibility requirements for those programs.

paragraph.heading: Clearinghouse.—
paragraph.content: The Secretary may establish a clearinghouse for tools, templates, guidance, and best practices on a page of the website of the Department that supports the purposes of this section.

subsection.heading: Notification to Congress.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this section, and not less frequently than once every 180 days thereafter until the date on which the Secretary determines that the requirements of this section have been met, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a notification that—

paragraph.chapeau: describes—

subparagraph.content: the programs and activities administered or overseen by the Freight Office; and
the status of those programs and activities;

paragraph.chapeau: identifies—

subparagraph.content: the number of employees working in the Freight Office as of the date of the notification;
the total number of employees expected to join the Freight Office to support the programs and activities described in paragraph (1); and

subparagraph.chapeau: the total number of positions that, as a result of the consolidation of offices under this section, were—

clause.content: eliminated; or
transferred, assigned, or joined to the Freight Office;

subparagraph.content: indicates whether the Secretary has consolidated into the Freight Office any office or office function pursuant to subsection (f)(1); and
if the Secretary has consolidated such an office or function, describes the rationale for the consolidation;
indicates whether the Secretary has eliminated any office pursuant to subsection (f)(2); and
if the Secretary has eliminated such an office, describes the rationale for the elimination;

paragraph.content: describes any other actions carried out by the Secretary to implement this section; and
describes any recommendations of the Secretary for legislation that may be needed to further implement this section.

paragraph.heading: Effect on other law.—
paragraph.content: Except as otherwise provided in this section, nothing in this section alters or affects any law (including regulations) with respect to a program referred to in subsection (d).

paragraph.heading: Effect on responsibilities of other agencies.—
paragraph.content: Except as otherwise provided in this section, nothing in this section abrogates the responsibilities of any agency, operating administration, or office within the Department that is otherwise charged by law (including regulations) with any aspect of program administration, oversight, or project approval or implementation with respect to a program or project subject to the responsibilities of the Freight Office under this section.

paragraph.heading: Effect on pending applications.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section affects any pending application under a program referred to in subsection (d) that was received by the Secretary on or before the date of enactment of the Surface Transportation Investment Act of 2021.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: There are authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary such sums as are necessary to carry out this section.

paragraph.heading: Certain activities.—
paragraph.content: Authorizations under subsections (f) and (g) are subject to appropriations.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section:

paragraph.heading: ARPA–I.—
paragraph.content: The term “ARPA–I” means the Advanced Research Projects Agency–Infrastructure established by subsection (b).

paragraph.heading: Department.—
paragraph.content: The term “Department” means the Department of Transportation.

paragraph.heading: Director.—
paragraph.content: The term “Director” means the Director of ARPA–I appointed under subsection (d).

paragraph.heading: Eligible entity.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “eligible entity” means—

subparagraph.content: a unit of State or local government;
an institution of higher education;
a commercial entity;
a research foundation;
a trade or industry research collaborative;
a federally funded research and development center;
a research facility owned or funded by the Department;
a collaborative that includes relevant international entities; and
a consortia of 2 or more entities described in any of subparagraphs (A) through (H).

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The term “infrastructure” means any transportation method or facility that facilitates the transit of goods or people within the United States (including territories).

subparagraph.heading: Inclusions.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The term “infrastructure” includes—

clause.content: roads;
highways;
bridges;
airports;
rail lines;
harbors; and
pipelines.

paragraph.heading: Secretary.—
paragraph.content: The term “Secretary” means the Secretary of Transportation.

subsection.heading: Establishment.—
subsection.chapeau: There is established within the Department an agency, to be known as the “Advanced Research Projects Agency–Infrastructure”, to support the development of science and technology solutions—

paragraph.content: to overcome long-term challenges; and
to advance the state of the art for United States transportation infrastructure.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The goals of ARPA–I shall be—

subparagraph.chapeau: to advance the transportation infrastructure of the United States by developing innovative science and technology solutions that—

clause.content: lower the long-term costs of infrastructure development, including costs of planning, construction, and maintenance;
reduce the lifecycle impacts of transportation infrastructure on the environment, including through the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions;
contribute significantly to improving the safe, secure, and efficient movement of goods and people; and
promote the resilience of infrastructure from physical and cyber threats; and

subparagraph.content: to ensure that the United States is a global leader in developing and deploying advanced transportation infrastructure technologies and materials.

paragraph.heading: Research projects.—
paragraph.chapeau: ARPA–I shall achieve the goals described in paragraph (1) by providing assistance under this section for infrastructure research projects that—

subparagraph.content: advance novel, early-stage research with practicable application to transportation infrastructure;
translate techniques, processes, and technologies, from the conceptual phase to prototype, testing, or demonstration;
develop advanced manufacturing processes and technologies for the domestic manufacturing of novel transportation-related technologies; and
accelerate transformational technological advances in areas in which industry entities are unlikely to carry out projects due to technical and financial uncertainty.

paragraph.heading: Appointment.—
paragraph.content: ARPA–I shall be headed by a Director, who shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.heading: Qualifications.—
paragraph.content: The Director shall be an individual who, by reason of professional background and experience, is especially qualified to advise the Secretary regarding, and manage research programs addressing, matters relating to the development of science and technology solutions to advance United States transportation infrastructure.

paragraph.heading: Relationship to secretary.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Director shall—

subparagraph.content: be located within the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology; and
report to the Secretary.

paragraph.heading: Relationship to other programs.—
paragraph.content: No other program within the Department shall report to the Director.

paragraph.heading: Responsibilities.—
paragraph.chapeau: The responsibilities of the Director shall include—

subparagraph.content: approving new programs within ARPA–I;
developing funding criteria, and assessing the success of programs, to achieve the goals described in subsection (c)(1) through the establishment of technical milestones;
administering available funding by providing to eligible entities assistance to achieve the goals described in subsection (c)(1);
terminating programs carried out under this section that are not achieving the goals of the programs; and
establishing a process through which eligible entities can submit to ARPA–I unsolicited research proposals for assistance under this section in accordance with subsection (f).

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Director shall establish and maintain within ARPA–I a staff with sufficient qualifications and expertise to enable ARPA–I to carry out the responsibilities under this section, in conjunction with other operations of the Department.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Director shall designate employees to serve as program directors for ARPA–I.

subparagraph.heading: Responsibilities.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Each program director shall be responsible for—

clause.content: establishing research and development goals for the applicable program, including by convening workshops and conferring with outside experts;
publicizing the goals of the applicable program;
soliciting applications for specific areas of particular promise, especially in areas that the private sector or the Federal Government are not likely to carry out absent assistance from ARPA–I;
establishing research collaborations for carrying out the applicable program;

clause.chapeau: selecting on the basis of merit each project to be supported under the applicable program, taking into consideration—

subclause.content: the novelty and scientific and technical merit of proposed projects;
the demonstrated capabilities of eligible entities to successfully carry out proposed projects;
the extent to which an eligible entity took into consideration future commercial applications of a proposed project, including the feasibility of partnering with 1 or more commercial entities; and
such other criteria as the Director may establish;

clause.content: identifying innovative cost-sharing arrangements for projects carried out or funded by ARPA–I;
monitoring the progress of projects supported under the applicable program;
identifying mechanisms for commercial application of successful technology development projects, including through establishment of partnerships between eligible entities and commercial entities; and

clause.chapeau: as applicable, recommending—

subclause.content: program restructuring; or
termination of applicable research partnerships or projects.

subparagraph.heading: Term of service.—
subparagraph.chapeau: A program director—

clause.content: shall serve for a term of 3 years; and
may be reappointed for any subsequent term of service.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Director may—

clause.content: make appointments of scientific, engineering, and professional personnel, without regard to the civil service laws;
fix the basic pay of such personnel at such rate as the Director may determine, but not to exceed level II of the Executive Schedule, without regard to the civil service laws; and

clause.chapeau: pay an employee appointed under this subparagraph payments in addition to basic pay, subject to the condition that the total amount of those additional payments for any 12-month period shall not exceed the least of—

subclause.content: an amount equal to 25 percent of the annual rate of basic pay of the employee; and
the amount of the applicable limitation for a calendar year under section 5307(a)(1) of title 5.

subparagraph.heading: Private recruiting firms.—
subparagraph.content: The Director may enter into a contract with a private recruiting firm for the hiring of qualified technical staff to carry out this section.

subparagraph.heading: Additional staff.—
subparagraph.content: The Director may use all authorities available to the Secretary to hire administrative, financial, and clerical staff, as the Director determines to be necessary to carry out this section.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: An eligible entity may submit to the Director an unsolicited research proposal at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Director may require, including a description of—

subparagraph.content: the extent of current and prior efforts with respect to the project proposed to be carried out using the assistance, if applicable; and
any current or prior investments in the technology area for which funding is requested, including as described in subsection (c)(2)(D).

paragraph.heading: Review.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Director—

subparagraph.chapeau: shall review each unsolicited research proposal submitted under paragraph (1), taking into consideration—

clause.content: the novelty and scientific and technical merit of the research proposal;
the demonstrated capabilities of the applicant to successfully carry out the research proposal;

the extent to which the applicant took into consideration future commercial applications of the proposed research project, including the feasibility of partnering with 1 or more commercial entities; and
such other criteria as the Director may establish;

subparagraph.chapeau: may approve a research proposal if the Director determines that the research—

clause.chapeau: is in accordance with—

subclause.content: the goals described in subsection (c)(1); or
an applicable transportation research and development strategic plan developed under section 6503; and

clause.content: would not duplicate any other Federal research being conducted or funded by another Federal agency; and

clause.chapeau: if funding is denied for the research proposal, shall provide to the eligible entity that submitted the proposal a written notice of the denial that, as applicable—

subclause.content: explains why the research proposal was not selected, including whether the research proposal fails to cover an area of need; and
recommends that the research proposal be submitted to another research program; or

clause.chapeau: if the research proposal is approved for funding, shall provide to the eligible entity that submitted the proposal—

subclause.content: a written notice of the approval; and
assistance in accordance with subsection (g) for the proposed research.

subsection.heading: Forms of Assistance.—
subsection.chapeau: On approval of a research proposal of an eligible entity, the Director may provide to the eligible entity assistance in the form of—

paragraph.content: a grant;
a contract;
a cooperative agreement;
a cash prize; or
another, similar form of funding.

paragraph.heading: Annual reports.—
paragraph.chapeau: For each fiscal year, the Director shall provide to the Secretary, for inclusion in the budget request submitted by the Secretary to the President under section 1108 of title 31 for the fiscal year, a report that, with respect to the preceding fiscal year, describes—

subparagraph.chapeau: the projects that received assistance from ARPA–I, including—

clause.content: each such project that was funded as a result of an unsolicited research proposal; and

each such project that examines topics or technologies closely related to other activities funded by the Department, including an analysis of whether the Director achieved compliance with subsection (i)(1) in supporting the project; and

subparagraph.content: the instances of, and reasons for, the provision of assistance under this section for any projects being carried out by industry entities.

paragraph.heading: Strategic vision roadmap.—
paragraph.content: Not later than October 1, 2022, and not less frequently than once every 4 years thereafter, the Director shall submit to the relevant authorizing and appropriations committees of Congress a roadmap describing the strategic vision that ARPA–I will use to guide the selection of future projects for technology investment during the 4 fiscal-year period beginning on the date of submission of the report.

subsection.heading: Coordination and Nonduplication.—
subsection.chapeau: The Director shall ensure that—

paragraph.chapeau: the activities of ARPA–I are coordinated with, and do not duplicate the efforts of, programs and laboratories within—

subparagraph.content: the Department; and
other relevant research agencies; and

paragraph.chapeau: no funding is provided by ARPA–I for a project, unless the eligible entity proposing the project—

subparagraph.content: demonstrates sufficient attempts to secure private financing; or
indicates that the project is not independently commercially viable.

subsection.heading: Federal Demonstration of Technologies.—
subsection.content: The Director shall seek opportunities to partner with purchasing and procurement programs of Federal agencies to demonstrate technologies resulting from activities funded through ARPA–I.

subsection.heading: Partnerships.—
subsection.chapeau: The Director shall seek opportunities to enter into contracts or partnerships with minority-serving institutions (as described in any of paragraphs (1) through (7) of section 371(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1067q(a)))—

paragraph.content: to accomplish the goals of ARPA–I;
to develop institutional capacity in advanced transportation infrastructure technologies and materials;
to engage underserved populations in developing, demonstrating, and deploying those technologies and materials; and
to otherwise address the needs of ARPA–I.

subsection.heading: University Transportation Centers.—
subsection.chapeau: The Director may—

paragraph.content: partner with university transportation centers under section 5505 to accomplish the goals, and address the needs, of ARPA–I; and

sponsor and select for funding, in accordance with section 5505, competitively selected university transportation center grants, in addition to the assistance provided under section 5505, to address targeted technology and material goals of ARPA–I.

paragraph.heading: Advisory committees.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Director may seek advice regarding any aspect of ARPA–I from—

subparagraph.content: an existing advisory committee, office, or other group within the Department; and

subparagraph.chapeau: a new advisory committee organized to support the programs of ARPA–I by providing advice and assistance regarding—

clause.content: specific program tasks; or
the overall direction of ARPA–I.

paragraph.heading: Additional sources.—
paragraph.chapeau: In carrying out this section, the Director may seek advice and review from—

subparagraph.content: the President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology;
the Advanced Research Projects Agency–Energy; and
any professional or scientific organization with expertise relating to specific processes or technologies under development by ARPA–I.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than December 27, 2024, the Secretary may enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Sciences under which the National Academy shall conduct an evaluation of the achievement by ARPA–I of the goals described in subsection (c)(1).

paragraph.heading: Inclusions.—
paragraph.chapeau: The evaluation under paragraph (1) may include—

subparagraph.content: a recommendation regarding whether ARPA–I should be continued;
a recommendation regarding whether ARPA–I, or the Department generally, should continue to allow entities to submit unsolicited research proposals; and

subparagraph.chapeau: a description of—

clause.content: the lessons learned from the operation of ARPA–I; and
the manner in which those lessons may apply to the operation of other programs of the Department.

paragraph.heading: Availability.—
paragraph.chapeau: On completion of the evaluation under paragraph (1), the evaluation shall be made available to—

subparagraph.content: Congress; and
the public.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Each type of information described in paragraph (2) that is collected by ARPA–I from eligible entities shall be considered to be—

subparagraph.content: commercial and financial information obtained from a person;
privileged or confidential; and
not subject to disclosure under section 552(b)(4) of title 5.

paragraph.heading: Description of types of information.—
paragraph.chapeau: The types of information referred to in paragraph (1) are—

subparagraph.content: information relating to plans for commercialization of technologies developed using assistance provided under this section, including business plans, technology-to-market plans, market studies, and cost and performance models;

information relating to investments provided to an eligible entity from a third party (such as a venture capital firm, a hedge fund, and a private equity firm), including any percentage of ownership of an eligible entity provided in return for such an investment;

subparagraph.chapeau: information relating to additional financial support that the eligible entity—

clause.content: plans to invest, or has invested, in the technology developed using assistance provided under this section; or
is seeking from a third party; and

subparagraph.content: information relating to revenue from the licensing or sale of a new product or service resulting from research conducted using assistance provided under this section.

subsection.heading: Effect on Existing Authorities.—
subsection.chapeau: The authority provided by this section—

paragraph.content: shall be in addition to any existing authority provided to the Secretary; and
shall not supersede or modify any other existing authority.

paragraph.heading: Authorization of appropriations.—
paragraph.content: There are authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary such sums as are necessary to carry out this section.

subparagraph.heading: Budget request.—
subparagraph.content: The budget request for ARPA–I shall be separate from the budget request of the remainder of the Department.

subparagraph.heading: Appropriations.—
subparagraph.content: The funding appropriated for ARPA–I shall be separate and distinct from the funding appropriated for the remainder of the Department.

paragraph.heading: Allocation.—
paragraph.chapeau: Of the amounts made available for a fiscal year under paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.chapeau: not less than 5 percent shall be used for technology transfer and outreach activities—

clause.content: in accordance with the goal described in subsection (c)(2)(D); and
within the responsibilities of the program directors described in subsection (e)(2)(B)(viii); and

subparagraph.content: none may be used for the construction of any new building or facility during the 5-year period beginning on the date of enactment of the Surface Transportation Investment Act of 2021.
